marc:datafield.marc:subfield: James Ford was a resident of Milton, Mass.

Collection includes a journal kept by James Ford during a trip to Frankfurt, Kentucky, to clear land titles confused by claims of squatters, French and Indian War veterans, and grantees of the Transylvania. Partly published in Bayrd Still, ed., "To the West on Business in 1804," Pennsylvannia Magazine of History and Biography, 64 (January, 1904), 1-21.
John Buchanan Floyd was a planter, lawyer, and governor of Virginia who later became the Secretary of War under President James Buchanan.
Papers include correspondence regarding of John Floyd's military campaigns and matters regarding troop movements, requests for supplies and army activities.
Peter Force was a resident of Washington, D.C. and newspaperman, Whig politician, mayor of Washington, D. C, and an historian.

Collection includes miscellaneous letters, including one from Thomas Loraine McKenney, 1825 August 15, concerning John C. Calhoun's role in passage of a treaty between the Creek Indians and the state of Georgia; a letter of introduction from George Perkins Marsh, 1849 September 5, on behalf of James Meacham, his successor as representative from Vermont; letters from David Lowry Swain, 1854 March 29 and 1856 August 14, sending Force writings on North Carolina history; and a letter from James Cochran Dobbin, U.S. Secretary of the Navy, 1856 May 31, concerning a suggestion made by Swain.
A.C. Ford was a resident of Eaton, Ohio.
This collection an item with the third stanza (with minor variations) of Stephen Collins Foster's "Old Folk's at Home." Under the stanza appear these words: "A. C. Ford's Ballad."

Correspondence of the Fleming family of Dutchville (Granville Co.), N.C., including comments on a smallpox epidemic, 1848; Whig politics in North Carolina, 1850; and the military situation after the first battle of Manassas (Bull Run), 1861.
Anna Fleming was a student, and resident of North Carolina.
Report cards of a student at Charlotte Female Institute, Charlotte, North Carolina.
W.H. Flinn was a merchant and resident of Georgia.

Letters to Flinn concerning the wholesale purchase of goods, including one letter bearing on the scarcity of textile goods for private consumption produced by the "Augusta Factory" after the factory was restricted to the manufacture of "shirting and sheeting" for the Confederate government.
John B. Foote was a Union soldier with the 117th Regiment, New York Infantry, from Utica (Oneida Co.), N.Y.

Collection includes letters to family members dating from Foote's entry into the army until his discharge. Topics including training around Washington, D.C., service at Suffolk, Petersburg, and Richmond, Va., and Folly and Charleston, S.C.; the capture of Fort Fisher; convalescence in military hospitals near Wilmington and New Bern, N.C.; camp life; confiscation of southern property; conscription of blacks; desertion; disease; health conditions; furloughs; morale; morals; prisoners; and transportation. There are a few letters from a cousin, Daniel P. Sanford, also a Union soldier, while camped at New Bern and Carolina City, N.C., relating to camp life and low pay.
David M. Ford was a soldier in the Union Army.
Letter to unidentified "Dear Friend" while serving with the 11th Connecticut Infantry at Hatteras Island, N.C. Includes comments on local inhabitants.
Henry Ford was a resident of Marshfield (Plymouth Co.), Mass.

Collection includes Civil War letters from John M. Ford, an enlisted man in the 37th Regiment of Massachusetts Volunteers, to his brother, Henry Ford, relating to the war in Virginia and Washington, D.C.
Rebecca J. Fleetwood was a resident of Hertford, N.C.
Personal letters, two of which were written from Chowan Female College, Murfreesboro, North Carolina.
Edward Flood was a Confederate officer, commander of the Pioneer Corps of Early's Division, Army of Northern Virginia, C.S.A.

Correspondence and military papers of Captain Flood relating to the rebuilding of bridges around Lexington and Staunton, Va., 1864-1865, and his application for Superintendent of Improvements for New Orleans, 1888.
Edward Follett was a Union soldier, from Bellevue (Easton Co.), Mich.

Includes records of Edward Follett's service with the 28th Michigan Volunteer Infantry, Nov., 1864-May, 1865, in Kentucky, Tennessee, Ohio, Virginia, and Washington, D.C.; in a hospital in Virginia or Washington, D.C.; at Fortress Monroe; and in North Carolina. A note at the end of the diary explains that Follett became ill and died on May 18, 1865.
George Fleming was a resident of Hanover County, Virginia.
Deeds and indentures relating to the transfer of land and the payment of debts.
Henry Stuart Foote was a resident of Washington D.C.
Collection is a letter from Henry Stuart Foote to Rev. C.K. Marshall.

Letters to James Fleming, corresponding secretary for the Confederate Survivors' Association, accepting or declining invitations to a reunion of this group. Included are letters from John Bratton, Joseph Brent, Winfield S. Featherston, Johnson Hagwood, James Henry Law, A. L. Long, N. Miller, Thomas Taylor Munford, and F. A. Sharp.
